elements.text: [Part One]
Ah, it's you. Again. Thought you'd given up on me. (sighs) I should have known you’d be back for more. I suppose you want me to talk, tell you everything. Well, I won't.
Footsteps approach.
I can't.
You know what will happen if you don't answer my questions, Doctor.
Yes, yes, I know. Physical violence, pain, torture, what have you. But I'm bored with that. Aren't you bored with all that?
There are other forms of torture besides the purely physical.
Ah, mental torture. Boring.
We'll see. I may have to introduce you to Mister Twyst, my expert on all matters painful.
So when does it start up again, then?
Oh, why, Doctor, I do believe you're looking forward to it.
Ow!
I know I am.
I can’t tell you anything. I can't. I keep telling you that.
Yes, I know, and I keep not believing you.
I wish I could tell you, I really do, but, well, this is a bit embarrassing. You see, I've lost my memory.
Oh, please, can't you come up with anything more original?
I know. I can scarcely believe it myself, but that's it. That's my excuse. Total amnesia. Sorry.
Oh, don't apologise. I like a challenge.
Footsteps, humming of machinery, slight echo of a large space.
Hello? Anyone down there? Marcus, I know you're there. Come on, stop hiding. Come on, come on.
Go away! Leave me alone.
Marcus, what are you doing down here?
Let go of me!
Calm down, calm down. I'm not going to hurt you, am I. It's me, Tessa. We're all in this together, remember?
You shouldn't have come after me. How did you find me?
Don't be an idiot. You're terrified. Not even these walls can hide that. The others have been looking for you everywhere.
I know. Why did you come after me?
I'm concerned for your welfare. It's in my job description.
What does that matter any more?
Well, technically it doesn't matter at all, but we've still got to look after each other. We're a team.
You don't really believe that.
No, well, maybe not, but Latch does, and he still thinks we can escape.
What do you think?
That there is no escape. Not from here.
And no place to hide?
So come on, we should go back to the others.
No! I'm not moving. It, it can't find me down here.
Well, /found you.
No, that's it. It's coming! It's found me! How did it find me? It's coming for me, Tessa. I'm next, I know I am!
Wait. Listen. I think you're right. Something is coming. I can feel it.
We've got to get away! Run! Run!
But I can't
It's come for me! We've got to split up. Leave me!
Marcus, I'll find the others. Run!
The Tardis materialises. The door opens. Hum of distant machinery and a slight echo.
Charley, that really hurt.
Oh, C'Rizz, you're such a child sometimes.

Now, now, Charley, C'Rizz. Let's not argue. People will think we're. Oh. No people. Now that's disappointing. Last time I attended the Festival of Ghana it was crowded, loads of people. Or was that the Festival of Jupiter?
It's deserted.
And very dark.
Nighttime, perhaps?
Could be, but we're indoors and there are no windows.
And no Festival of any kind.
You know, I think the Tardis is being deliberately obtuse.
You mean this isn't the Festival of Ghana?
Of course it isn't.
Perhaps you made a mistake with the coordinates, Doctor.
No, no, no, I double-checked. This is definitely Earth. It's the Tardis, I tell you. She's just mucking about. I wonder where we are exactly?
Somewhere dark and cold. Metallic walls. Not very inspiring.
It could be anywhere.
No, it's definitely somewhere. Here's a door, look.
Opens door.
Hello? Anyone home?
Oh! Oh, what's that smell?
Human sweat. Fear. Unmistakable.
Urgh, sorry I asked. Must we go in?
It's still a bit dark.
Is there a light switch or something?
Wait, I've got a torch somewhere. Ah ha. (click) Here.
Keep away!
God!
Hold on, it's all right.
Keep away!
We don't mean you any harm. It's all right.
It's in my head. It's in my head!
What is? Try to relax.
Get it out! Get it out of my head!
Oh, my God, he's having a fit!
Charley, C'Rizz, help me. Keep hold of him. Keep hold. What's your name?
Ma, Marcus.
All right, Marcus, very pleased to meet you. I'm the Doctor.
Keep away from me! Argh!
Oh, Doctor, what happened to him?
I wish I knew. I've never seen anything like it.
His skull just seemed to
Look at his face, look at his eyes.
Oh, he looks terrified.
He died in absolute fear. But there's something else.
Yes?
There's something about his eyes. Something, oh, I don't know, empty almost. More than just dead.
Some people say the eyes are the window to the soul.
But then some people have more poetic sense than common sense. You're right, C'Rizz, there is something else, and it feels like an itch in my own mind that I just can't scratch.
What could to that to a person, Doctor? Was there something inside his head, do you think?
An itch he couldn't scratch? Possibly. Anyway, I doubt this chap is all on his own here. There must be other people about. People who will want to know about this.
He doesn't seem to be carrying any kind of ID.
Or any personal possessions at all. Look at his clothes. Plain overalls. They don't even fit properly
Nothing to indicate what he's doing here, or where here actually is. Come on, we'd better find someone.
We can't just leave him like that.
Why not?
There's nothing we can do for him now, Charley, except maybe find his friends or family.
And what did this to him.
Of course.
Come on.
Footsteps.
Latch, is that you?
It's me.
Any sign of the others?
No, nothing. How about you?
Tessa's all right, I think, but I can't make any contact with Marcus.
Nor me.
He's dead, isn't he? We're being picked off one by one.
We can't know for sure what's happened yet. If Tessa is okay, then there's still a chance.
Chance for what? That we might actually survive?
There has to be a way out, Jane. There has to be. It's just a case of finding it.
Finding it before we're killed, you mean. At this rate I don't fancy our chances.
Wait, there's Tessa. We were beginning to think we'd lost you, too.
Latch, Jane.
Where's Marcus? Did you find him?
He's. I don't know.
Where is he? Skulking in some dark corner, scared out wits?
He was (pause) hiding.
There's no point in hiding. Did you tell him that?
Yes, I told him that, but I think it might be too late.
I knew it.
What do you mean? They got him, got Marcus?
Yes.
We've got to get out of here.
There is no way out.
So you keep telling us. Ever thought of trying to find a way out?
You just won't give up, will you, Latch?
I'm a survivor, Tessa. If you won't help us, then at least don't hinder us. We intend to get out of here. I intend to find the person responsible for this.
Then what?
kill them. What else.
You could help us, Tessa. You know you could.
I think we're beyond help now, all of us.
So, you still expect me to believe you don't know what's going on, that you have no idea how you came to be here?
That's right, none at all. My mind is a complete blank.
Oh, you Psychs. You think you're so superior.
Psychs?
Psychics, telepaths. You trying to tell me you've forgotten that you're telepathic?
I'm not telepathic.
Of course you are.
No, no, really, I'm not.
How would you know? You can't remember anything.
Well, I don't fee/ telepathic. I'm sure I'd notice if I was. And I can't tell what you are thinking, beyond the obvious, of course.
Ah, but your special powers won't work in here. You see, the walls are lined with psychic energy suppressants.
Ah.
Sound familiar?
No.
You're either very clever, Doctor, or incredibly stupid. I can't decide which.
Tell me when you've worked it out. I'd quite like to know myself.
What's it like, then, hmm? Suddenly being normal, reduced to a bog-standard human.
I honestly don't know how to answer that.
I think we need something to jog your memory, Doctor.
How about hypnotic memory regression? Have you thought of that?
Oh, I was thinking of something simpler. A little reminder of your recent past.
That would be interesting.
We'll see. Bring him in!
Door opens.
Doctor!
Hello, there.
I thought you were dead. What are they doing with us? Where are we?
Well, Doctor?
I'm sorry, I've never met this person before.
Are you seriously trying to tell me you don't recognise this, this thing?
C’RIZZ: Doctor?
I'm sorry, I don't know you. And I think I would remember a face like yours. Believe me, I'm as disappointed as you obviously are.
What happened to you?

Well, I appear to have lost my memory. Careless, I know, but there you are. This gentleman here has been trying to help me regain it, using, well, various methods, none of which have been either pleasant or efficacious.
You mustn't forget me, or Charley, or what's happened to us.
It's a bit of a puzzle. You see, I may indeed know you, but I don't remember you. C'Rizz, did you say? Unusual name. Where are you from? Maybe it will jog
Enough, enough.
But I was just getting going.
You're wasting my time.
Hold on a minute. This chap seems to know me. Maybe he can answer some of your questions. Ask him some. Go on.
I already have.
He already has.

He’s useless to me. He's obviously not even human, and so was never a Psych. But we musin't hold that against him. I had hoped that he might prove effective in forcing you to answer some questions though, Doctor. You know, rather than hurting you, I could hurt him.
That's not fair.
Of course not, but you are my prisoner and I am your captor, and I have to claim some advantage.
What do you want to know?
Oh, what's this, cooperation?
I will tell you anything if it will stop you hurting someone. I'll tell you the sky is falling down and the moon is made of Gruyeére if any of that will stop you hurting him.
Doctor, I am sorry. Latch said
Latch? Latch? Gordon Latch? I might have known he'd still be alive. Who else?
I don't know their names.
Maybe we can find a way to help you remember. Remove him.
Wait. Wait, wait, wait. Where are you taking him? He's injured. He needs medical attention.
From you, I suppose?
Whoever he is, I don't want to hurt him. Leave him alone.
Oh, is that it? Are you finished?
I don't like to see anyone suffer, that I do know.
How can you be sure? You don't remember. Perhaps you were a killer, a murderer, a torturer.
I'm sure I'd remember something like that.
How?
(sighs) Here's a clue. I am the Doctor. Not the Murderer or the Torturer. I'll leave that kind of stuff to you.
Hmm. So, what would you do if I told you I'm not going to leave C'Rizz alone, hmm? That I'm going to hurt him.
Don't.

I could tear out his reptilian tongue, burn out his eyes, crack his head open like an egg, if I have to. Anything to make you talk, to make you tell me the things I want to hear. Well? Nothing to say? No heart-breaking plea, no, no confession?
Do what you want. It won't make any difference. I can't tell you what you want to know.
You can, and you will.
Where did you last see Marcus?
He was hiding in the lower level, one of the ancillary walkways, under a stairwell. He was scared. I think he could sense something was coming after him.
You ran away.
We both ran. We split up. Something was coming. We just panicked and ran. Marcus went one way and I went the other. I don't know what happened to him.
I think we can all guess.
We don't have to guess. Come on, you both know he's dead.
I lost any trace of him some time ago. He just blanked out on me. I didn't know what to think.
We all thought the same thing. You know we did. A thought like that, we all share them.
All right, all right. But it's not so easy for us, Jane. You're the telepathy expert. You must have had a better idea of what happened. Think!
It's very confusing. If I try to make contact with him, there's, there's nothing there. Just a blank. Like you said, it could mean Marcus is dead. But there's something else. Someone else.
Someone else?
Can't you feel it? A stranger. A doctor, here in the Cube.
A doctor?
You mean another Psych? Is that possible?
I don't know, but there's definitely someone else in the Cube. Someone telepathic. And that means they're in trouble.
Clang!
What was that?
A door closing somewhere?
Or opening.
Clang!
There it goes again. I don't like the sound of it. Oh, can't we go back to the Tardis?
Oh, rather. Please, Doctor?
What's got into the pair of you? Ooo, spooky noises.
And someone with his skull turned inside out. Let's not forget that.
Clang! And a faint hissing sound.
Actually, I don't much like the sound of that either. Very strange acoustics, this place. Now, where's that tuning fork?
Doctor, may I suggest the better part of valour?
All right, a discreet exit, just this once. Come on, back the way we came.
Oh, can we move a bit quicker, please?
This way. Come on, hurry up.
I didn't think we'd come this far.

The Tardis is just up ahead. Keep going. The architectural layout here is rather brutal, but I've an excellent sense of direction. It's all based on quadrilaterals, have you noticed? Around the corner, go on.
Oh no.
This door wasn't here before.
Perhaps it closed behind us.
Oh, let's just go through and we can worry about it later.
It's locked.
It can't be.
Let's have a look. Hmm. Sonic screwdriver number three, I should think.
Er, Doctor, please be quick. That thing, I think it's gaining on us.
Won't be a tick. Nearly there. That's my beauty. Come on. One, two and we're nearly there.
Thud. Silence.
I don't believe it. Doctor, I. Doctor?
What is it?
The Doctor, he's gone.
What? He can't have gone.
Oh, no.
Where's the Tardis?
What's going on?
Down here. There's a trace, a feeling. Yes, this is near to where they came in.
Slow down, Jane. I don't understand. Came in? How could they get in? They can't have teleported in. Speaking of which, where's Tessa got to?
Maybe she teleported.
Very funny.
Shh. There's been some sort of psychic disturbance down here.
The stranger, the doctor.
Maybe, yes. He, he was here. I can sense it, can't you?
There is something, now you mention it, just on the edge of ESP. Oh, damn this place. We're practically blind in here.
Deaf, dumb and blind. Oh no.
Marcus.
Marcus. Just like the others
Oh, what a mess. Poor kid. Hell, we've got to get out of here. I've got to get out of here!
We will, we will. But think about it. There's someone else in the Cube now. I can sense him. A doctor. Somehow he got in here. And if he could get in
Then he can get out.
Exactly.
Breathless.
I can't believe it's gone! Not the Tardis.
Quick, help me shut this door.
But the Doctor.
He's not here and that thing is. Now come on!
Of, it's stuck!
No, just heavy. Come on, heave.
Clang.
I doubt that'll hold for long.
But where's the Tardis? I mean, this is where we left it, isn't it?
Well, maybe, maybe the Doctor got in, thought we were with him and just took off!
What?
I don't know.
Growl.
Whatever that thing is back there, it's not giving up.
It's coming through!
Run!
Clang.
Too late!
Run!
This way. Over here, all of you!
What? Who are you?
No time for questions. Move it!
Follow us if you don't want to lose your minds.
Come on, Doctor. Don't give up so easily. We've barely begun.
I need to rest. My head hurts.
That's understandable, but I really don’t care. I want to know what happened in there. The full story. Specifically I'd like to know how you got out.
I can't. I can't remember.
Come on. Think, man. Lives could depend on it. The life of your friend C'Rizz, for instance.
Don't hurt him any more, please.
Give me a reason not to, Doctor. Tell me what happened in there. What do you know about the thing that attacked you? Did you see it? How did you get away? Come on, man, I haven't got all day!
I need to rest.
You know, C’Rizz is quite a mess. Want to see him again?
No.
But he's an old friend.
Then I certainly don't want to see him.
Oh, have it your own way. We'll just have to hurt him some more.
All right, all right, all right, stop, stop.
This had better be good, Doctor.
What do you want to know?
The same as before. Did you see it?

I, I don't, I don't know. I mean I think I did. I just don't want to remember. Some mental block, I think. Post-traumatic stress disorder. It’s there, in my mind. A memory like a worm, turning and twisting in the dark. Blood red, blind. It's there. It's there.
You did see it.
(sotto) Yes. But I can't, I mustn't think about it any more.
You've done well, but I need to know more.
I don't want to think about it.
I still need to know who is left alive in there.
Footsteps, clang.
Who exactly are you?
Gordon Latch. This is Jane Thirgood.
Hi there.
Very pleased to meet you. I'm
C'Rizz. Hello.
Er, yes, that's right.
And you're Charley.
But we've never met. How do you know who we are?
A very good question. I hope you have a good answer.
Which unit were you with?
Unit?
Which Psych team?
Oh, there seems to be some sort of misunderstanding. We're not with any team.
How did you get in here?
Well, we were just passing, and the Doctor brought us here.
Doctor?
Liar.
I beg your pardon?
You're lying. I can see it. It's as clear as day. What about the blue box?
You've seen the Tardis?
Not exactly seen, no.
Do you know the way out?
Listen, maybe we should all just start again.
I said, do you know the way out of here?
Do you know where the Doctor is?
I thought he was with you. Where is he?
Clang!
We don't have time to talk about this now, Latch. We have to keep moving.
Come on, let's move.
Why?
Look, if that thing catches us.
That thing? What thing? What is it, exactly?
Clang!
Latch, come on. We need to to move!
Come on. This way, all of you. If we can reach the upper level fast enough, we might stand a chance.
But what are we running from?
I'll explain later.
I hate it when people say that.
Come on, hurry!
Why? Hmm? Why do you want to know about Latch, was it?
Oh yes, a very dangerous man. A criminal, a murderer. You could say Gordon Latch put the psycho in psychokinetic. He’s the leader.
Leader of what?
You lot. The Psychs. He was one of the first.
First?

To be converted. One of the first successful ones, anyway. Superb telekineticist. Absolutely lethal. Telepathic assassination, that was his thing. He had a mind like a steel trap. One thought was all it took and pftt, you're dead. Oh, you don't look convinced, Doctor, but it's true. Gordon Latch could kill you as easily as (snaps fingers)
I suppose he uses telekinesis to cut off every electrochemical reaction in the brain. That's quite a talent.
It’s not a talent. I made him like that.
I'm sure he's very grateful. But what, may I ask, was the point?
No. I'm interrogating you. Gordon Latch, Marcus Lenn, Jane Thirgood and Tessa Waylund. Are they still alive?
Marcus is dead. Something turned his head inside out. I don't remember anyone else.
Just as you don't remember C'Rizz, or Charley Pollard.
Who?
Your other friend, according to C'Rizz.

You'd be better off asking him these questions. He seems to have all the answers. Don't you understand? It's like there's something missing inside my head, my mind. I can feel the hole where it used to be. Knowledge, information, emotions, people, places, colours, all the things that made me who I am, are gone. I'm just nothing.
I'm heartbroken.
We've got to keep going.
It can't be far behind.
It, it, you keep saying it.
Where are we going?
Nowhere's safe. We just have to keep moving until it loses us or gives up.
Oh, I was afraid you'd say that.
Will somebody please tell us what it is we're running from?
You mean you really don't know?
Of course he knows.
I promise you I don't.
You must know.
Look what is this place?
Oh, you can't be serious!
Tell us where we are.
We're in the Cube.
The Cube?
You really don't know what's going on, do you?
Can't you tell? I thought you could both read my mind.
What?
They can read our minds. That's how they knew our names. And about the Doctor.
Is this true?
Yes, of course it is. We're Psychs.
You can read our thoughts?
We could, although I can't read anything now. Not even this close.
No, me neither.
That's because I've suppressed my brain's natural alpha waves, and those of Charley, just enough to stop you picking up any stray thoughts we might have. Our thoughts are private.
Very good. I'm impressed.
I never knew you were telepathic, C'Rizz.
No, just something I picked up. Something I saved from someone I once, well, there's a lot you don't know about me, Charley.
C'Rizz, what are you talking about?
We really don't have the time right now.
Jane's right. We need to move to the upper level. This way. We can talk later.
Tell me about the Brainworm, Doctor. You've seen it. It attacked you, damaged you. It's loose in the Cube and I want to know what it is and why it's there.
I don't want to remember. Please don't make me.

At the first sign of trouble in there, the Cube's surveillance system shut down. You are my only source of information, the only way I have of knowing what's going on in there. Now come on. Just a bit further. Think back. Tell me about the Brainworm.
I've seen it? I've seen it.
Yes. Tell me what you saw.
I saw. I saw. No, I can still see it. Ah! It's in my mind. It's in my mind! My own mind!
Shh. No, no, control yourself, Doctor. Doctor, I want you to remember the Brainworm. Remember what you saw, not what it did to you.
It scratched, inside my mind. It hurts.
That's all right, that's all right. The pain is good. Yes, it means that you're still alive in there, still feeling. It didn't kill you.
It should have.
But it didn't. You're still here, with me.
That's what I meant.
Running footsteps.
Follow me. We've got to get to the top level.
But what is that thing?
Brainworm.
Oh, sounds delightful.
Don't joke. If it catches you, you'd be better off dead.
Why? What does it
We haven't got time for all these questions now.
Clang!
Quick, all through here.
Hurry!
Clang!
That was too close, Latch.
Agreed. Is everyone all right?
Yes.
Just about.
Good. We're safe up here.
And here is?
The top level of the Cube. The Brainworm won't come up here.
Are you sure?
It's never come up this far before.
Yeah, relax, We're secure.
You think so?
Yes, I'm sure.
Clang! Hissing sound. All cry out.
This way! Run!
Oh no, no.
C'Rizz!
Run, Charley. Run!

parts.searchable_dialogue:
DOCTOR: Ah, it's you. Again. Thought you'd given up on me. (sighs) I should have known you’d be back for more. I suppose you want me to talk, tell you everything. Well, I won't.
DOCTOR: I can't.
RAWDEN: You know what will happen if you don't answer my questions, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Yes, yes, I know. Physical violence, pain, torture, what have you. But I'm bored with that. Aren't you bored with all that?
RAWDEN: There are other forms of torture besides the purely physical.
DOCTOR: Ah, mental torture. Boring.
RAWDEN: We'll see. I may have to introduce you to Mister Twyst, my expert on all matters painful.
DOCTOR: So when does it start up again, then?
RAWDEN: Oh, why, Doctor, I do believe you're looking forward to it.
DOCTOR: Ow!
RAWDEN: I know I am.
DOCTOR: I can’t tell you anything. I can't. I keep telling you that.
RAWDEN: Yes, I know, and I keep not believing you.
DOCTOR: I wish I could tell you, I really do, but, well, this is a bit embarrassing. You see, I've lost my memory.
RAWDEN: Oh, please, can't you come up with anything more original?
DOCTOR: I know. I can scarcely believe it myself, but that's it. That's my excuse. Total amnesia. Sorry.
RAWDEN: Oh, don't apologise. I like a challenge.
TESSA: Hello? Anyone down there? Marcus, I know you're there. Come on, stop hiding. Come on, come on.
MARCUS: Go away! Leave me alone.
TESSA: Marcus, what are you doing down here?
MARCUS: Let go of me!
TESSA: Calm down, calm down. I'm not going to hurt you, am I. It's me, Tessa. We're all in this together, remember?
MARCUS: You shouldn't have come after me. How did you find me?
TESSA: Don't be an idiot. You're terrified. Not even these walls can hide that. The others have been looking for you everywhere.
MARCUS: I know. Why did you come after me?
TESSA: I'm concerned for your welfare. It's in my job description.
MARCUS: What does that matter any more?
TESSA: Well, technically it doesn't matter at all, but we've still got to look after each other. We're a team.
MARCUS: You don't really believe that.
TESSA: No, well, maybe not, but Latch does, and he still thinks we can escape.
MARCUS: What do you think?
TESSA: That there is no escape. Not from here.
MARCUS: And no place to hide?
TESSA: So come on, we should go back to the others.
MARCUS: No! I'm not moving. It, it can't find me down here.
TESSA: Well, /found you.
MARCUS: No, that's it. It's coming! It's found me! How did it find me? It's coming for me, Tessa. I'm next, I know I am!
TESSA: Wait. Listen. I think you're right. Something is coming. I can feel it.
MARCUS: We've got to get away! Run! Run!
TESSA: But I can't
MARCUS: It's come for me! We've got to split up. Leave me!
TESSA: Marcus, I'll find the others. Run!
C'RIZZ: Charley, that really hurt.
CHARLEY: Oh, C'Rizz, you're such a child sometimes.
DOCTOR: Now, now, Charley, C'Rizz. Let's not argue. People will think we're. Oh. No people. Now that's disappointing. Last time I attended the Festival of Ghana it was crowded, loads of people. Or was that the Festival of Jupiter?
CHARLEY: It's deserted.
C'RIZZ: And very dark.
CHARLEY: Nighttime, perhaps?
DOCTOR: Could be, but we're indoors and there are no windows.
CHARLEY: And no Festival of any kind.
DOCTOR: You know, I think the Tardis is being deliberately obtuse.
C'RIZZ: You mean this isn't the Festival of Ghana?
DOCTOR: Of course it isn't.
CHARLEY: Perhaps you made a mistake with the coordinates, Doctor.
DOCTOR: No, no, no, I double-checked. This is definitely Earth. It's the Tardis, I tell you. She's just mucking about. I wonder where we are exactly?
C'RIZZ: Somewhere dark and cold. Metallic walls. Not very inspiring.
CHARLEY: It could be anywhere.
DOCTOR: No, it's definitely somewhere. Here's a door, look.
DOCTOR: Hello? Anyone home?
CHARLEY: Oh! Oh, what's that smell?
DOCTOR: Human sweat. Fear. Unmistakable.
CHARLEY: Urgh, sorry I asked. Must we go in?
C'RIZZ: It's still a bit dark.
CHARLEY: Is there a light switch or something?
DOCTOR: Wait, I've got a torch somewhere. Ah ha. (click) Here.
MARCUS: Keep away!
CHARLEY: God!
DOCTOR: Hold on, it's all right.
MARCUS: Keep away!
DOCTOR: We don't mean you any harm. It's all right.
MARCUS: It's in my head. It's in my head!
DOCTOR: What is? Try to relax.
MARCUS: Get it out! Get it out of my head!
CHARLEY: Oh, my God, he's having a fit!
DOCTOR: Charley, C'Rizz, help me. Keep hold of him. Keep hold. What's your name?
MARCUS: Ma, Marcus.
DOCTOR: All right, Marcus, very pleased to meet you. I'm the Doctor.
MARCUS: Keep away from me! Argh!
CHARLEY: Oh, Doctor, what happened to him?
DOCTOR: I wish I knew. I've never seen anything like it.
C'RIZZ: His skull just seemed to
DOCTOR: Look at his face, look at his eyes.
CHARLEY: Oh, he looks terrified.
C'RIZZ: He died in absolute fear. But there's something else.
DOCTOR: Yes?
C'RIZZ: There's something about his eyes. Something, oh, I don't know, empty almost. More than just dead.
CHARLEY: Some people say the eyes are the window to the soul.
DOCTOR: But then some people have more poetic sense than common sense. You're right, C'Rizz, there is something else, and it feels like an itch in my own mind that I just can't scratch.
C'RIZZ: What could to that to a person, Doctor? Was there something inside his head, do you think?
DOCTOR: An itch he couldn't scratch? Possibly. Anyway, I doubt this chap is all on his own here. There must be other people about. People who will want to know about this.
C'RIZZ: He doesn't seem to be carrying any kind of ID.
CHARLEY: Or any personal possessions at all. Look at his clothes. Plain overalls. They don't even fit properly
DOCTOR: Nothing to indicate what he's doing here, or where here actually is. Come on, we'd better find someone.
CHARLEY: We can't just leave him like that.
C'RIZZ: Why not?
DOCTOR: There's nothing we can do for him now, Charley, except maybe find his friends or family.
C'RIZZ: And what did this to him.
CHARLEY: Of course.
DOCTOR: Come on.
JANE: Latch, is that you?
LATCH: It's me.
JANE: Any sign of the others?
LATCH: No, nothing. How about you?
JANE: Tessa's all right, I think, but I can't make any contact with Marcus.
LATCH: Nor me.
JANE: He's dead, isn't he? We're being picked off one by one.
LATCH: We can't know for sure what's happened yet. If Tessa is okay, then there's still a chance.
JANE: Chance for what? That we might actually survive?
LATCH: There has to be a way out, Jane. There has to be. It's just a case of finding it.
JANE: Finding it before we're killed, you mean. At this rate I don't fancy our chances.
LATCH: Wait, there's Tessa. We were beginning to think we'd lost you, too.
TESSA: Latch, Jane.
JANE: Where's Marcus? Did you find him?
TESSA: He's. I don't know.
LATCH: Where is he? Skulking in some dark corner, scared out wits?
TESSA: He was (pause) hiding.
LATCH: There's no point in hiding. Did you tell him that?
TESSA: Yes, I told him that, but I think it might be too late.
JANE: I knew it.
LATCH: What do you mean? They got him, got Marcus?
TESSA: Yes.
JANE: We've got to get out of here.
TESSA: There is no way out.
LATCH: So you keep telling us. Ever thought of trying to find a way out?
TESSA: You just won't give up, will you, Latch?
LATCH: I'm a survivor, Tessa. If you won't help us, then at least don't hinder us. We intend to get out of here. I intend to find the person responsible for this.
TESSA: Then what?
LATCH: kill them. What else.
JANE: You could help us, Tessa. You know you could.
TESSA: I think we're beyond help now, all of us.
RAWDEN: So, you still expect me to believe you don't know what's going on, that you have no idea how you came to be here?
DOCTOR: That's right, none at all. My mind is a complete blank.
RAWDEN: Oh, you Psychs. You think you're so superior.
DOCTOR: Psychs?
RAWDEN: Psychics, telepaths. You trying to tell me you've forgotten that you're telepathic?
DOCTOR: I'm not telepathic.
RAWDEN: Of course you are.
DOCTOR: No, no, really, I'm not.
RAWDEN: How would you know? You can't remember anything.
DOCTOR: Well, I don't fee/ telepathic. I'm sure I'd notice if I was. And I can't tell what you are thinking, beyond the obvious, of course.
RAWDEN: Ah, but your special powers won't work in here. You see, the walls are lined with psychic energy suppressants.
DOCTOR: Ah.
RAWDEN: Sound familiar?
DOCTOR: No.
RAWDEN: You're either very clever, Doctor, or incredibly stupid. I can't decide which.
DOCTOR: Tell me when you've worked it out. I'd quite like to know myself.
RAWDEN: What's it like, then, hmm? Suddenly being normal, reduced to a bog-standard human.
DOCTOR: I honestly don't know how to answer that.
RAWDEN: I think we need something to jog your memory, Doctor.
DOCTOR: How about hypnotic memory regression? Have you thought of that?
RAWDEN: Oh, I was thinking of something simpler. A little reminder of your recent past.
DOCTOR: That would be interesting.
RAWDEN: We'll see. Bring him in!
C'RIZZ: Doctor!
DOCTOR: Hello, there.
C'RIZZ: I thought you were dead. What are they doing with us? Where are we?
RAWDEN: Well, Doctor?
DOCTOR: I'm sorry, I've never met this person before.
RAWDEN: Are you seriously trying to tell me you don't recognise this, this thing?
RAWDEN: C’RIZZ: Doctor?
DOCTOR: I'm sorry, I don't know you. And I think I would remember a face like yours. Believe me, I'm as disappointed as you obviously are.
C'RIZZ: What happened to you?
DOCTOR: Well, I appear to have lost my memory. Careless, I know, but there you are. This gentleman here has been trying to help me regain it, using, well, various methods, none of which have been either pleasant or efficacious.
C'RIZZ: You mustn't forget me, or Charley, or what's happened to us.
DOCTOR: It's a bit of a puzzle. You see, I may indeed know you, but I don't remember you. C'Rizz, did you say? Unusual name. Where are you from? Maybe it will jog
RAWDEN: Enough, enough.
DOCTOR: But I was just getting going.
RAWDEN: You're wasting my time.
DOCTOR: Hold on a minute. This chap seems to know me. Maybe he can answer some of your questions. Ask him some. Go on.
RAWDEN: I already have.
C'RIZZ: He already has.
RAWDEN: He’s useless to me. He's obviously not even human, and so was never a Psych. But we musin't hold that against him. I had hoped that he might prove effective in forcing you to answer some questions though, Doctor. You know, rather than hurting you, I could hurt him.
DOCTOR: That's not fair.
RAWDEN: Of course not, but you are my prisoner and I am your captor, and I have to claim some advantage.
DOCTOR: What do you want to know?
RAWDEN: Oh, what's this, cooperation?
DOCTOR: I will tell you anything if it will stop you hurting someone. I'll tell you the sky is falling down and the moon is made of Gruyeére if any of that will stop you hurting him.
C'RIZZ: Doctor, I am sorry. Latch said
RAWDEN: Latch? Latch? Gordon Latch? I might have known he'd still be alive. Who else?
C'RIZZ: I don't know their names.
RAWDEN: Maybe we can find a way to help you remember. Remove him.
DOCTOR: Wait. Wait, wait, wait. Where are you taking him? He's injured. He needs medical attention.
RAWDEN: From you, I suppose?
DOCTOR: Whoever he is, I don't want to hurt him. Leave him alone.
RAWDEN: Oh, is that it? Are you finished?
DOCTOR: I don't like to see anyone suffer, that I do know.
RAWDEN: How can you be sure? You don't remember. Perhaps you were a killer, a murderer, a torturer.
DOCTOR: I'm sure I'd remember something like that.
RAWDEN: How?
DOCTOR: (sighs) Here's a clue. I am the Doctor. Not the Murderer or the Torturer. I'll leave that kind of stuff to you.
RAWDEN: Hmm. So, what would you do if I told you I'm not going to leave C'Rizz alone, hmm? That I'm going to hurt him.
DOCTOR: Don't.
RAWDEN: I could tear out his reptilian tongue, burn out his eyes, crack his head open like an egg, if I have to. Anything to make you talk, to make you tell me the things I want to hear. Well? Nothing to say? No heart-breaking plea, no, no confession?
DOCTOR: Do what you want. It won't make any difference. I can't tell you what you want to know.
RAWDEN: You can, and you will.
LATCH: Where did you last see Marcus?
TESSA: He was hiding in the lower level, one of the ancillary walkways, under a stairwell. He was scared. I think he could sense something was coming after him.
JANE: You ran away.
TESSA: We both ran. We split up. Something was coming. We just panicked and ran. Marcus went one way and I went the other. I don't know what happened to him.
LATCH: I think we can all guess.
JANE: We don't have to guess. Come on, you both know he's dead.
TESSA: I lost any trace of him some time ago. He just blanked out on me. I didn't know what to think.
JANE: We all thought the same thing. You know we did. A thought like that, we all share them.
LATCH: All right, all right. But it's not so easy for us, Jane. You're the telepathy expert. You must have had a better idea of what happened. Think!
JANE: It's very confusing. If I try to make contact with him, there's, there's nothing there. Just a blank. Like you said, it could mean Marcus is dead. But there's something else. Someone else.
TESSA: Someone else?
JANE: Can't you feel it? A stranger. A doctor, here in the Cube.
LATCH: A doctor?
TESSA: You mean another Psych? Is that possible?
JANE: I don't know, but there's definitely someone else in the Cube. Someone telepathic. And that means they're in trouble.
C'RIZZ: What was that?
CHARLEY: A door closing somewhere?
DOCTOR: Or opening.
C'RIZZ: There it goes again. I don't like the sound of it. Oh, can't we go back to the Tardis?
CHARLEY: Oh, rather. Please, Doctor?
DOCTOR: What's got into the pair of you? Ooo, spooky noises.
C'RIZZ: And someone with his skull turned inside out. Let's not forget that.
DOCTOR: Actually, I don't much like the sound of that either. Very strange acoustics, this place. Now, where's that tuning fork?
CHARLEY: Doctor, may I suggest the better part of valour?
DOCTOR: All right, a discreet exit, just this once. Come on, back the way we came.
CHARLEY: Oh, can we move a bit quicker, please?
DOCTOR: This way. Come on, hurry up.
CHARLEY: I didn't think we'd come this far.
DOCTOR: The Tardis is just up ahead. Keep going. The architectural layout here is rather brutal, but I've an excellent sense of direction. It's all based on quadrilaterals, have you noticed? Around the corner, go on.
CHARLEY: Oh no.
C'RIZZ: This door wasn't here before.
DOCTOR: Perhaps it closed behind us.
CHARLEY: Oh, let's just go through and we can worry about it later.
C'RIZZ: It's locked.
CHARLEY: It can't be.
DOCTOR: Let's have a look. Hmm. Sonic screwdriver number three, I should think.
C'RIZZ: Er, Doctor, please be quick. That thing, I think it's gaining on us.
DOCTOR: Won't be a tick. Nearly there. That's my beauty. Come on. One, two and we're nearly there.
C'RIZZ: I don't believe it. Doctor, I. Doctor?
CHARLEY: What is it?
C'RIZZ: The Doctor, he's gone.
CHARLEY: What? He can't have gone.
C'RIZZ: Oh, no.
CHARLEY: Where's the Tardis?
C'RIZZ: What's going on?
JANE: Down here. There's a trace, a feeling. Yes, this is near to where they came in.
LATCH: Slow down, Jane. I don't understand. Came in? How could they get in? They can't have teleported in. Speaking of which, where's Tessa got to?
JANE: Maybe she teleported.
LATCH: Very funny.
JANE: Shh. There's been some sort of psychic disturbance down here.
LATCH: The stranger, the doctor.
JANE: Maybe, yes. He, he was here. I can sense it, can't you?
LATCH: There is something, now you mention it, just on the edge of ESP. Oh, damn this place. We're practically blind in here.
JANE: Deaf, dumb and blind. Oh no.
LATCH: Marcus.
JANE: Marcus. Just like the others
LATCH: Oh, what a mess. Poor kid. Hell, we've got to get out of here. I've got to get out of here!
JANE: We will, we will. But think about it. There's someone else in the Cube now. I can sense him. A doctor. Somehow he got in here. And if he could get in
LATCH: Then he can get out.
JANE: Exactly.
CHARLEY: I can't believe it's gone! Not the Tardis.
C'RIZZ: Quick, help me shut this door.
CHARLEY: But the Doctor.
C'RIZZ: He's not here and that thing is. Now come on!
CHARLEY: Of, it's stuck!
C'RIZZ: No, just heavy. Come on, heave.
C'RIZZ: I doubt that'll hold for long.
CHARLEY: But where's the Tardis? I mean, this is where we left it, isn't it?
C'RIZZ: Well, maybe, maybe the Doctor got in, thought we were with him and just took off!
CHARLEY: What?
C'RIZZ: I don't know.
CHARLEY: Whatever that thing is back there, it's not giving up.
C'RIZZ: It's coming through!
CHARLEY: Run!
C'RIZZ: Too late!
CHARLEY: Run!
LATCH: This way. Over here, all of you!
C'RIZZ: What? Who are you?
JANE: No time for questions. Move it!
LATCH: Follow us if you don't want to lose your minds.
RAWDEN: Come on, Doctor. Don't give up so easily. We've barely begun.
DOCTOR: I need to rest. My head hurts.
RAWDEN: That's understandable, but I really don’t care. I want to know what happened in there. The full story. Specifically I'd like to know how you got out.
DOCTOR: I can't. I can't remember.
RAWDEN: Come on. Think, man. Lives could depend on it. The life of your friend C'Rizz, for instance.
DOCTOR: Don't hurt him any more, please.
RAWDEN: Give me a reason not to, Doctor. Tell me what happened in there. What do you know about the thing that attacked you? Did you see it? How did you get away? Come on, man, I haven't got all day!
DOCTOR: I need to rest.
RAWDEN: You know, C’Rizz is quite a mess. Want to see him again?
DOCTOR: No.
RAWDEN: But he's an old friend.
DOCTOR: Then I certainly don't want to see him.
RAWDEN: Oh, have it your own way. We'll just have to hurt him some more.
DOCTOR: All right, all right, all right, stop, stop.
RAWDEN: This had better be good, Doctor.
DOCTOR: What do you want to know?
RAWDEN: The same as before. Did you see it?
DOCTOR: I, I don't, I don't know. I mean I think I did. I just don't want to remember. Some mental block, I think. Post-traumatic stress disorder. It’s there, in my mind. A memory like a worm, turning and twisting in the dark. Blood red, blind. It's there. It's there.
RAWDEN: You did see it.
DOCTOR: (sotto) Yes. But I can't, I mustn't think about it any more.
RAWDEN: You've done well, but I need to know more.
DOCTOR: I don't want to think about it.
RAWDEN: I still need to know who is left alive in there.
CHARLEY: Who exactly are you?
LATCH: Gordon Latch. This is Jane Thirgood.
JANE: Hi there.
C'RIZZ: Very pleased to meet you. I'm
JANE: C'Rizz. Hello.
C'RIZZ: Er, yes, that's right.
LATCH: And you're Charley.
CHARLEY: But we've never met. How do you know who we are?
C'RIZZ: A very good question. I hope you have a good answer.
LATCH: Which unit were you with?
CHARLEY: Unit?
LATCH: Which Psych team?
CHARLEY: Oh, there seems to be some sort of misunderstanding. We're not with any team.
LATCH: How did you get in here?
C'RIZZ: Well, we were just passing, and the Doctor brought us here.
JANE: Doctor?
LATCH: Liar.
CHARLEY: I beg your pardon?
LATCH: You're lying. I can see it. It's as clear as day. What about the blue box?
C'RIZZ: You've seen the Tardis?
JANE: Not exactly seen, no.
LATCH: Do you know the way out?
CHARLEY: Listen, maybe we should all just start again.
LATCH: I said, do you know the way out of here?
CHARLEY: Do you know where the Doctor is?
LATCH: I thought he was with you. Where is he?
JANE: We don't have time to talk about this now, Latch. We have to keep moving.
LATCH: Come on, let's move.
CHARLEY: Why?
LATCH: Look, if that thing catches us.
C'RIZZ: That thing? What thing? What is it, exactly?
JANE: Latch, come on. We need to to move!
LATCH: Come on. This way, all of you. If we can reach the upper level fast enough, we might stand a chance.
CHARLEY: But what are we running from?
LATCH: I'll explain later.
C'RIZZ: I hate it when people say that.
JANE: Come on, hurry!
DOCTOR: Why? Hmm? Why do you want to know about Latch, was it?
RAWDEN: Oh yes, a very dangerous man. A criminal, a murderer. You could say Gordon Latch put the psycho in psychokinetic. He’s the leader.
DOCTOR: Leader of what?
RAWDEN: You lot. The Psychs. He was one of the first.
DOCTOR: First?
RAWDEN: To be converted. One of the first successful ones, anyway. Superb telekineticist. Absolutely lethal. Telepathic assassination, that was his thing. He had a mind like a steel trap. One thought was all it took and pftt, you're dead. Oh, you don't look convinced, Doctor, but it's true. Gordon Latch could kill you as easily as (snaps fingers)
DOCTOR: I suppose he uses telekinesis to cut off every electrochemical reaction in the brain. That's quite a talent.
RAWDEN: It’s not a talent. I made him like that.
DOCTOR: I'm sure he's very grateful. But what, may I ask, was the point?
RAWDEN: No. I'm interrogating you. Gordon Latch, Marcus Lenn, Jane Thirgood and Tessa Waylund. Are they still alive?
DOCTOR: Marcus is dead. Something turned his head inside out. I don't remember anyone else.
RAWDEN: Just as you don't remember C'Rizz, or Charley Pollard.
DOCTOR: Who?
RAWDEN: Your other friend, according to C'Rizz.
DOCTOR: You'd be better off asking him these questions. He seems to have all the answers. Don't you understand? It's like there's something missing inside my head, my mind. I can feel the hole where it used to be. Knowledge, information, emotions, people, places, colours, all the things that made me who I am, are gone. I'm just nothing.
RAWDEN: I'm heartbroken.
LATCH: We've got to keep going.
JANE: It can't be far behind.
C'RIZZ: It, it, you keep saying it.
CHARLEY: Where are we going?
LATCH: Nowhere's safe. We just have to keep moving until it loses us or gives up.
CHARLEY: Oh, I was afraid you'd say that.
C'RIZZ: Will somebody please tell us what it is we're running from?
JANE: You mean you really don't know?
LATCH: Of course he knows.
C'RIZZ: I promise you I don't.
LATCH: You must know.
CHARLEY: Look what is this place?
LATCH: Oh, you can't be serious!
C'RIZZ: Tell us where we are.
JANE: We're in the Cube.
CHARLEY: The Cube?
LATCH: You really don't know what's going on, do you?
C'RIZZ: Can't you tell? I thought you could both read my mind.
CHARLEY: What?
C'RIZZ: They can read our minds. That's how they knew our names. And about the Doctor.
CHARLEY: Is this true?
LATCH: Yes, of course it is. We're Psychs.
CHARLEY: You can read our thoughts?
JANE: We could, although I can't read anything now. Not even this close.
LATCH: No, me neither.
C'RIZZ: That's because I've suppressed my brain's natural alpha waves, and those of Charley, just enough to stop you picking up any stray thoughts we might have. Our thoughts are private.
LATCH: Very good. I'm impressed.
CHARLEY: I never knew you were telepathic, C'Rizz.
C'RIZZ: No, just something I picked up. Something I saved from someone I once, well, there's a lot you don't know about me, Charley.
CHARLEY: C'Rizz, what are you talking about?
JANE: We really don't have the time right now.
LATCH: Jane's right. We need to move to the upper level. This way. We can talk later.
RAWDEN: Tell me about the Brainworm, Doctor. You've seen it. It attacked you, damaged you. It's loose in the Cube and I want to know what it is and why it's there.
DOCTOR: I don't want to remember. Please don't make me.
RAWDEN: At the first sign of trouble in there, the Cube's surveillance system shut down. You are my only source of information, the only way I have of knowing what's going on in there. Now come on. Just a bit further. Think back. Tell me about the Brainworm.
DOCTOR: I've seen it? I've seen it.
RAWDEN: Yes. Tell me what you saw.
DOCTOR: I saw. I saw. No, I can still see it. Ah! It's in my mind. It's in my mind! My own mind!
RAWDEN: Shh. No, no, control yourself, Doctor. Doctor, I want you to remember the Brainworm. Remember what you saw, not what it did to you.
DOCTOR: It scratched, inside my mind. It hurts.
RAWDEN: That's all right, that's all right. The pain is good. Yes, it means that you're still alive in there, still feeling. It didn't kill you.
DOCTOR: It should have.
RAWDEN: But it didn't. You're still here, with me.
DOCTOR: That's what I meant.
LATCH: Follow me. We've got to get to the top level.
C'RIZZ: But what is that thing?
JANE: Brainworm.
CHARLEY: Oh, sounds delightful.
JANE: Don't joke. If it catches you, you'd be better off dead.
CHARLEY: Why? What does it
LATCH: We haven't got time for all these questions now.
LATCH: Quick, all through here.
JANE: Hurry!
JANE: That was too close, Latch.
LATCH: Agreed. Is everyone all right?
CHARLEY: Yes.
C'RIZZ: Just about.
LATCH: Good. We're safe up here.
C'RIZZ: And here is?
LATCH: The top level of the Cube. The Brainworm won't come up here.
CHARLEY: Are you sure?
JANE: It's never come up this far before.
LATCH: Yeah, relax, We're secure.
C'RIZZ: You think so?
LATCH: Yes, I'm sure.
LATCH: This way! Run!
JANE: Oh no, no.
CHARLEY: C'Rizz!
C'RIZZ: Run, Charley. Run!

elements.text: [Part Two]
This way, quick! Come on, keep up.
Oh, but what about C'Rizz? We can't just
Be quiet and run.
We can't just leave him.
Forget about him!
What?
Look, he's dead. Keep moving or we will be too.
Oh!
Er, hello? Anybody there? I can't. Anyone at all? Charley? Charley? Latch? Jane?
Rumble of heavy door opening.
Hello?
Shall we have a little light on the situation? (click) Ah. There you are.
Who are you? Where am I?
How did you get here? No idea. I found you unconscious outside, where we found the other one earlier.
The Doctor?
That's the one.
Untie me and take me to him, immediately.
Later. I want answers to a few questions first.
Say please.
How did you get out of the prison?
The what?
The Cube.
Ah, is that what it is.
Well?
I don't know. We were being attacked by something called a Brainworm.
Why?
I don't know.
I think you and I need to have a nice long talk.
Breathless.
Can we just slow down a minute?
Too dangerous.
What did that thing do to C'Rizz?
The Brainworm killed him.
Killed him? No, we've got to go back.
Not a chance.
We don't know for sure what the Brainworm really is, Charley. All we know is that it's deadly and it's in here with us, in the Cube.
It gets inside your head. It's not pretty.
Oh no. The man by the Tardis.
Marcus? It was Marcus. She's seen him. Latch.
Oh, stop reading my mind!
Sorry, Charley. I can't help it. At this range, your thoughts and memories are pretty obvious. Your memory of Marcus is very strong. He didn't deserve to die like that.
He was so scared. He was only young.
Twenty years old. Our youngest recruit. Full of energy and optimism, until he came here.
Recruit? You're soldiers?
The army used us for specialist missions. The kind where psychic powers could be useful.
Oh, I see. Like reconnaissance, I suppose. Spying by telepathy. You could just close your eyes or whatever and see what the enemy was thinking, what they were going to do next.
Telepathic eavesdropping, teleport incursions, even telekinetic assassination. You name it, we did it.
Did?
The war's over, Charley. We won. Complete victory, thanks to us. Normal soldiers were discharged, but we're not normal.
I don't understand.
The war couldn't be won by conventional means. They had to come up with an alternative, a new kind of weapon.
Psychic soldiers?
It was the only way in the end.
You sound like an apologist for Rawden.
Rawden?
Eric Rawden, the man who found a way to artificially develop ESP.
Rawden made us like this, engineered us to develop psi-powers for use on the battlefield.
We were volunteers.
But now they won't release us. Won't even let us see our families, our children.
Who'd want us? They say no one likes a psychic. We can read anyone's mind, open any door.
Kill someone with a single thought.
There are no secrets around us.
So what happened? How did you end up in this place?

The Cube is a prison. A prison built for telepaths. You see, we're no longer brave soldiers fighting for our world. Rawden's reclassified us as criminals, killers and murderers. We're serving a death sentence now.
You've done well, Doctor. We're nearly there. You deserve a reward.

Forget it. You honestly don't think I know what kind of place this is? Do you think I've never been locked up before? The Cube is a prison. A terrible, sad, wicked, inhuman prison. But I've escaped from more prisons than you've had hot dinners.
And that is what you think you're going to do?
If I can.
Doctor, what you think is immaterial. What you Know, however, is more interesting.
I don't know anything.

Oh, but you do. Buried in that memory of yours is the information I need. I intend to dig it out, piece by piece if I have to. I couldn't care less if it hurts. I'll just keep digging and digging and digging until I get what I want. Everything you know about the Brainworm. Everything. You have no hope, no rights, no chance of escape. All you have, Doctor, is me.
So what happened to your comrades, the other Psychs who were in the armed forces?
They're dead. Most of them were given the treatment.
The treatment?
First they used a machine to change our brainwaves, to increase our natural psychic ability, make us telepathic, make us into Psychs.
How? You mean using surgery?
Only they didn't really know what they were doing. We weren't much more than a last desperate experiment. When the war was over, they said they could use the same machine to reverse the process.
It was supposed to remove telepathic powers from the human brain, reset our brainwave patterns to normal. They said it was a kind of cure.
But it didn't work. The effect was temporary. Whatever they did to alter our minds, to make us telepathic, was permanent. There is no cure.
That's horrible.
Some of the people they treated died. Massive brain damage caused by psychic shock. After the first few, they stopped the treatment programme altogether, locked us all in the Cube and left us to rot.
In prison?
You said it.
Just because you're telepathic?
Another reason to thank Rawden.
But he made you like this in the first place.
Our usefulness is over. We've served our purpose. Rawden couldn't cure us so he
locked us up in here and left us to die.
Why don't you just use your special powers to escape? Teleportation and that kind of thing?
The Cube is built from a special metal which nullifies psychic energy.
But your powers still work. You can still read my mind.
We still have some powers, but they're weakened in here.
So the walls in this place act as a sort of psychic ball and chain.
Or a muzzle.
How many of you are there in here now?
Well, now that Marcus is dead, that only leaves Latch and me. And Tessa, of course.
Tessa?
The weak link in our chain. A loner. No, scratch that. A loser.
Some say she was the most powerful Psych they ever made.
That's debatable.
Latch and Tessa never really hit it off.
Tessa isn't a team player. We were supposed to be a team, a unit.
What happened?
Tessa preferred to work on her own, closed her mind against us.
She was never against us, Latch. She thought you could kill her.
She knew I never meant that. It was just an excuse.
But she was a powerful Psych. Teleport was her speciality. We always thought if anyone could find a way out of the Cube, then Tessa could.
At the moment I'll settle for just finding the Doctor and C'Rizz.
They're both dead.
You don't know that for certain.
Don't tell me you've fallen for it as well, Jane? The Brainworm got them both.
No, I won't believe that until. Well, until I have proof.
It wouldn't be pretty.
Even so.
Clang.
What was that?
We've waited too long. Come on! Let's move.
The Brainworm?
You can generally hear it coming. Let's go.
Well, where are we going?
You want to find your friends, don't you? Come on, then. Just don't blame me if you don't like what you find.
So what's next in your little bully's handbook of terror? Electric shock treatment? Matchsticks under the fingernails?

We're a bit more advanced than that. We have a machine here, Doctor, which rewrites brainwaves. We used it to increase extra-sensory perception. That's how we created Latch and his kind. Psychic soldiers. It was probably a mistake, in hindsight, but the war. Well, to tell you the truth, it was a desperate time.
And it called for desperate measures, I suppose.
Exactly. I suppose it's true that making the Psychs was a terrible thing. It wasn't a decision that I took lightly. But I genuinely believe the Psychs won us the war.
Bravo. Did they know that their reward would be a prison sentence?
Perhaps they should have foreseen it, yes.
(laughs) Being psychic.
(laughs) Yes. You know, you and I, we could be friends, Doctor.
I very much doubt it.
Aw. We're both perceptive, intelligent men, strong-willed, determined. Yes, we're very alike.
Now you are frightening me.
Good.
Running water.
Tessa? Tessa, are you in there?
You know I am, Latch. You'd better come in. Who's that with you? Charley who?
Pollard. And please stop trying to read my mind.
It's hard not to. Your thoughts light up like halogen in this place.
Bang.
Ow!
It's a bit cramped, I know. I've fallen on hard times lately.
Haven't we all?
Are you all right, Charley?
Oh, a bang on the head, that's all. Oh. Well, I wouldn't try and read my mind right now, if I were you. It's likely to be a bit of a mess.
Now don't be silly. Here, let me see.
Ow!
Oh, that's quite a lump. Never mind, it'll soon (pause) go away.
Oh. Oh, that is better. Thank you. What did you do?
Nothing, really. A parlour trick. I have healing hands. Cuts and contusions a speciality.
Tessa was our medic. She's being modest.
But this is quite a deputation. Come to make me an offer I can't refuse, Latch?
You've nothing to fear from me.
Is that so? You hate me, but you need me. That can be a very ugly combination.
We've not come here to fight.
No, you've come to parade your hostage.
Hostage?
That's what they're thinking, Charley. That they can use you to get out of here. And they may be right.
Is this true?
We just want to get out of here.
And we'll do whatever we have to.
Latch, will you never give up?
You know the answer to that.

You don't need me as a hostage. To be honest, I don't think there's anyone here who'd care what happens to me. But I'm willing to help, for what it's worth. Surely there must be some way out? I mean, if there's a way in, then
Makes sense. Yes.
Tessa was our infiltration expert. In the old days, no one was better at teletransportation than Tessa.
And now?
I can't teleport myself out of here. It's psych proof.
I know.
But how did you and your chums get in? What is it about that big blue box of yours?
The Tardis! You've seen it? Where is it?
I can see it in your thoughts. Big and blue and full of hope and promise and safety. But what is it?
Well, er, it's difficult to say.

A time machine? That can't be right. Yet I can see you believe it. Oh, and they think I'm crazy. But I can see you don't really know all that much about it, how it works or anything. Not that that matters much now. Your Tardis isn't here any more, but the Doctor. Yes! He's the one. He's the one you want.
Will you stop reading my mind, please. It's horrible.
What? Wait, no. This Doctor person you keep thinking about.
The Doctor's dead. The Brainworm got him.
We don't know that for sure.
Don't we? I can sense your thoughts, and those of Latch and Jane here. I cannot, however, detect the Doctor's thoughts anywhere. Nothing at all.
What? What about C'Rizz?
Nothing. I'm sorry, Charley. Your friends are gone, just like Marcus.
No.
This brainwave machine of yours, how does it work?
I'm not technically minded. I believe it involves something called braincell augmentation, yes?
That's interesting.
Oh? Why?
Oh, nothing. It's just a thought.
What, exactly?
Well, I imagine a machine like that, if it was sophisticated enough, could be used to repair neural damage.
I think I see what you're getting at, Doctor. It might even be able to help you regain your memory. Quite ingenious. Are you serious?
Well, no, actually. It's ridiculous. Forget I said it. Too risky, for one thing. It was just a mad thought. Ignore me.
You're not an easy man to ignore, Doctor. You know, I think it's high time I introduced you to Mister Twyst.
Mister Twyst?

My technical man. And also my coercion specialist. Very thorough. Your friend C'Rizz possesses a tough exoskeleton that made normal methods of physical brutality ineffective, but Mister Twyst can be rather inventive when necessary.
That doesn't sound very promising. Can I see him?
Twyst? Of course.
No, I mean the other prisoner. The one you said is my friend.
Yes, he's with Twyst in the treatment centre.
Treatment?
Yes. You know, it's perfect, Doctor. Think of it. The machine we used on the Psychs. I'm sure it could be used to rehabilitate your memory. It's a very good idea.
Um.
We did try to use it to help the Psychs regain their humanity. Some of them didn't respond very well, it has to be said.
I'm not sure I like the sound of that.
Brain damage wasn't uncommon. Some of them just struck lucky and died on the operating table.
Operating table?
Figure of speech. The actual process is quite straight forward, I'm told. Just took us a while to perfect the technique. Or so we thought.
Why, what happened?
Don't ask me. It's a technical problem. They say it means nothing to me. Some sort of malfunction with the equipment.
Malfunction? What exactly did
But I'm sure Mister Twyst could find a usable workaround.
And you've got C'Rizz in there?
Well, yes. For questioning. But as I said, Mister Twyst had to be quite inventive.
But you don't know they're dead, not for sure. Your telepathy can't tell you that.
Their thoughts are gone.
Gone, not dead. Don't you see? It just means they're not in the Cube anymore! I have to find them.
There's no way out of the Cube.
Oh, there must be. If they're not dead, there must be.
Charley and her friends got in. Maybe their blue box
Oh, it isn't anywhere to be found at the moment. Oh, come on! We have to try.
Don't you think we already have?
I thought you were the one who wasn't ever going to give up for anything.
She's right, Latch.
Argh. You don't understand. This place is killing us. The stuff in the walls is like something pressing down on our heads all of the time. We've got to get out!
Then you only have one hope, and that's the Doctor. We have to find him.
(groans) Oh, please, no more.
Ah, you're awake.
No more.
Oh, come now, C'Rizz, come now. Don't be silly. There's plenty more to come.
Please, no.
That's enough. Don't talk. Save your strength, my friend. You're going to need it.
Who are you? Why are you doing this to me?
You can call me Mister Twyst. Now, oh, where were we? I've quite forgotten. I'm going to have to waste time reactivating those nerve endings for a start. Open old wounds, as it were.
I won't tell you any more.

There you go again, C'Rizz, worrying about telling me things. I've already told you I'm not interested. This isn't an interrogation. There's nothing you can tell me that will make the slightest difference. There, you just relax. Well, not too much. We've got to make sure you're able to feel something, haven't we? Now, let me see. Shall we start with the electric saw?
Saw buzzes. Door opens.
Mister Rawden. What a lovely surprise.
Saw turned off.
At ease, Twyst. I have the prisoner with me.
Oh, hello.
What's going on in here? Give me that!
Hey!
What have you been doing?
Don't get so excited, Doctor.
This is a disgrace, Rawden. You said that this was a treatment unit for telepaths.
The psychotronic adjustment unit, to be precise.
Keep out of this, you.
I'm engaged in important scientific research.
I'll bet you are. Let me see him. It's all right, I'm a doctor. Let me have a look.
(whimpering) Doctor.
Good man. Let's have a look at you. You've really gone to town on him, you butcher.
I barely started.
Doctor, help me please.
Yes, I will, I will. What was your name again?
Doctor, I didn't bring you here to demonstrate your bedside manner.
Don't you have any analgesics in here? Painkillers of some kind?
Not much call for them here, actually.
How badly are you hurt? Is anything broken?
I don't know.
Can you move?
Oh, the pain.
Doctor, I brought you here to rewrite your brainwaves.
And you really think that that would work?
Twyst?

Er, well, it's possible, I suppose. The brain surgery techniques are fairly straight forward. We originally used the machine to make normal people into Psychs, but unfortunately when we reversed the process to turn Psychs back into normal people
It didn't work.
Not quite in the way we'd hoped, no.
What exactly went wrong, Twyst? Rawden said something about a malfunction. Perhaps I can help. I'm good with gadgets, I think.
Well, I don't know.
How does it work? Something about cellular augmentation, wasn't it. Rewriting brainwaves. Sounds pretty simple.
Perhaps a demonstration, Mister Twyst?
I've always preferred to show rather than tell.
Let's not be too hasty. I wouldn't want to put you to any trouble.
Oh, don't worry about that, Doctor. I'm sure we can find a volunteer.
Twyst chuckles.
Footsteps.
Charley, hold it.
Let go of me!
Just stop a momert, will you?
The Doctor and C'Rizz are more than just friends. They're like family to me.
I understand.
I'm certain there must be a way out of the Cube.
Maybe.
No, you have to believe.
I'm sorry, Charley. You saw what happened to Marcus. Latch is right when he says the same thing could have happened to the Doctor.
Anything's possible, believe me. We're always escaping from inescapable things.
Always?
It's a way of life when you travel in the Tardis.
So where are you heading?
Well, we should start by going back to where we last saw him. Where the Brainworm attacked.
No, too dangerous.
That's true wherever we go now. Nowhere's safe any more.
So what are we going to do, just stand here? Please, I just want to find my friends.
Latch, think of it. A way out of here.
Latch?
We might as well die trying to do something.
And this is the resequencing beam laser here.
And this directly rewrites the brain's alpha waves.
Complete neural restructure. I can see you're impressed, Doctor.
Then you must be quite blind, Mister Twyst. What does this bit do?
Don't touch that! Please. It reverses the process, and we've only recently recalibrated the forceshields.
Sorry. So this is actually the same machine that was used to enhance the patient's latent telepathic abilities?
That is correct. Every volunteer soldier was subjected to a thorough ESP test first. Only the highest scoring candidates were even considered for brain cell augmentation.
Even so, the process must have been very dangerous.
Very much so. But we learnt a lot as we went along. In the end, our success rate was good enough to make the project worthwhile.
An elite unit of psychic soldiers.
Bending spoons for King and Country, hmm?

Their talents were considerably more useful than that, and extremely dangerous. Take Gordon Latch, for example. We made him into the supreme psychic warrior, a mind as deadly as any gun. Small wonder some of them found the psychic transition difficult to cope with.
I don't doubt it.
But we offered them a cure.
When you'd got what you wanted.
We were trying to help them, Doctor. We owed them that much. We made them into freaks.
And that's when you recalibrated the machinery to reverse the process.
So that we could turn their special powers off, allow them to function as normal human beings.
Normal human beings? You mean those that can love and hate, laugh and cry, sleep and eat, as opposed to telepathic ones who can do all those things as well?
You don't realise how dangerous they were.
How dangerous you made them.
Their telepathic powers changed them, made them unreliable. They were no longer like us. But I don't expect you to appreciate this.

Appreciate it? What I don't appreciate is why you've got C'Rizz wired into this machine. After all, there's not much point in trying the machine out on him. That exoskeleton cranium will prevent effective psycho-surgery.
Whereas you, Doctor, would make the perfect patient. You said yourself it might be just the thing to help you cure your amnesia.
Or kill him in the process.
kill or cure. Sorry, I don't like the odds.
Of course, this machine would probably boil C'Rizz's brain in his skull.
It's your choice, Doctor. Subject yourself to the machine. Let's try and reawaken those telepathic memories. Or allow us to continue with C'Rizz.
I am not going anywhere near that thing. It would be like trying to unpick stitches with
a garden fork, and there are enough mindless zombies in the universe without me joining them.
Very well. Mister Twyst, continue with the operation on C'Rizz.
Yes, sir.
Wait, stop.
No, no. Doctor, let them do it. It doesn't matter any more.
Be quiet, C'Rizz. This has got nothing to do with you.
Actually
Synaptic control programme activated.
Machine starts up.
Well, Doctor, what's it to be?
Psycho-electric power at optimum capacity.
Rawden, stop him!
Virtual scalpel to align for neural excoriation.
Goodbye, Doctor.
Rawden, for pity's sake, I can't let this happen.
There's only one way of stopping it, Doctor.
Ready to begin psychic extraction.
All right, all right!
Twyst.
No, Doctor, don't.
C'Rizz, I haven't any choice.
Swap them over, Twyst.
Doctor, I'm sorry. I'm sorry. Please.
It has to be this way.
Into position, please, Doctor. There. Just relax.
Don't touch me. I can manage myself.
Interesting decision, Doctor.
Murderers. You'll kill him.
Oh, it could be much worse than that, I'm afraid.
This isn't murder, it's research. Ready, Doctor?
Just get on with it.
Doctor!
In your own time, Mister Twyst. Maximum power.
Maximum power.
No!
No! Argh!

parts.searchable_dialogue:
LATCH: This way, quick! Come on, keep up.
CHARLEY: Oh, but what about C'Rizz? We can't just
JANE: Be quiet and run.
CHARLEY: We can't just leave him.
JANE: Forget about him!
CHARLEY: What?
LATCH: Look, he's dead. Keep moving or we will be too.
CHARLEY: Oh!
C'RIZZ: Er, hello? Anybody there? I can't. Anyone at all? Charley? Charley? Latch? Jane?
C'RIZZ: Hello?
TWYST: Shall we have a little light on the situation? (click) Ah. There you are.
C'RIZZ: Who are you? Where am I?
TWYST: How did you get here? No idea. I found you unconscious outside, where we found the other one earlier.
C'RIZZ: The Doctor?
TWYST: That's the one.
C'RIZZ: Untie me and take me to him, immediately.
TWYST: Later. I want answers to a few questions first.
C'RIZZ: Say please.
TWYST: How did you get out of the prison?
C'RIZZ: The what?
TWYST: The Cube.
C'RIZZ: Ah, is that what it is.
TWYST: Well?
C'RIZZ: I don't know. We were being attacked by something called a Brainworm.
TWYST: Why?
C'RIZZ: I don't know.
TWYST: I think you and I need to have a nice long talk.
CHARLEY: Can we just slow down a minute?
JANE: Too dangerous.
CHARLEY: What did that thing do to C'Rizz?
LATCH: The Brainworm killed him.
CHARLEY: Killed him? No, we've got to go back.
LATCH: Not a chance.
JANE: We don't know for sure what the Brainworm really is, Charley. All we know is that it's deadly and it's in here with us, in the Cube.
LATCH: It gets inside your head. It's not pretty.
CHARLEY: Oh no. The man by the Tardis.
JANE: Marcus? It was Marcus. She's seen him. Latch.
CHARLEY: Oh, stop reading my mind!
JANE: Sorry, Charley. I can't help it. At this range, your thoughts and memories are pretty obvious. Your memory of Marcus is very strong. He didn't deserve to die like that.
CHARLEY: He was so scared. He was only young.
LATCH: Twenty years old. Our youngest recruit. Full of energy and optimism, until he came here.
CHARLEY: Recruit? You're soldiers?
LATCH: The army used us for specialist missions. The kind where psychic powers could be useful.
CHARLEY: Oh, I see. Like reconnaissance, I suppose. Spying by telepathy. You could just close your eyes or whatever and see what the enemy was thinking, what they were going to do next.
LATCH: Telepathic eavesdropping, teleport incursions, even telekinetic assassination. You name it, we did it.
CHARLEY: Did?
JANE: The war's over, Charley. We won. Complete victory, thanks to us. Normal soldiers were discharged, but we're not normal.
CHARLEY: I don't understand.
JANE: The war couldn't be won by conventional means. They had to come up with an alternative, a new kind of weapon.
CHARLEY: Psychic soldiers?
JANE: It was the only way in the end.
LATCH: You sound like an apologist for Rawden.
CHARLEY: Rawden?
JANE: Eric Rawden, the man who found a way to artificially develop ESP.
LATCH: Rawden made us like this, engineered us to develop psi-powers for use on the battlefield.
JANE: We were volunteers.
LATCH: But now they won't release us. Won't even let us see our families, our children.
JANE: Who'd want us? They say no one likes a psychic. We can read anyone's mind, open any door.
LATCH: Kill someone with a single thought.
JANE: There are no secrets around us.
CHARLEY: So what happened? How did you end up in this place?
LATCH: The Cube is a prison. A prison built for telepaths. You see, we're no longer brave soldiers fighting for our world. Rawden's reclassified us as criminals, killers and murderers. We're serving a death sentence now.
RAWDEN: You've done well, Doctor. We're nearly there. You deserve a reward.
DOCTOR: Forget it. You honestly don't think I know what kind of place this is? Do you think I've never been locked up before? The Cube is a prison. A terrible, sad, wicked, inhuman prison. But I've escaped from more prisons than you've had hot dinners.
RAWDEN: And that is what you think you're going to do?
DOCTOR: If I can.
RAWDEN: Doctor, what you think is immaterial. What you Know, however, is more interesting.
DOCTOR: I don't know anything.
RAWDEN: Oh, but you do. Buried in that memory of yours is the information I need. I intend to dig it out, piece by piece if I have to. I couldn't care less if it hurts. I'll just keep digging and digging and digging until I get what I want. Everything you know about the Brainworm. Everything. You have no hope, no rights, no chance of escape. All you have, Doctor, is me.
CHARLEY: So what happened to your comrades, the other Psychs who were in the armed forces?
LATCH: They're dead. Most of them were given the treatment.
CHARLEY: The treatment?
LATCH: First they used a machine to change our brainwaves, to increase our natural psychic ability, make us telepathic, make us into Psychs.
CHARLEY: How? You mean using surgery?
LATCH: Only they didn't really know what they were doing. We weren't much more than a last desperate experiment. When the war was over, they said they could use the same machine to reverse the process.
JANE: It was supposed to remove telepathic powers from the human brain, reset our brainwave patterns to normal. They said it was a kind of cure.
LATCH: But it didn't work. The effect was temporary. Whatever they did to alter our minds, to make us telepathic, was permanent. There is no cure.
CHARLEY: That's horrible.
LATCH: Some of the people they treated died. Massive brain damage caused by psychic shock. After the first few, they stopped the treatment programme altogether, locked us all in the Cube and left us to rot.
CHARLEY: In prison?
LATCH: You said it.
CHARLEY: Just because you're telepathic?
LATCH: Another reason to thank Rawden.
CHARLEY: But he made you like this in the first place.
LATCH: Our usefulness is over. We've served our purpose. Rawden couldn't cure us so he
LATCH: locked us up in here and left us to die.
CHARLEY: Why don't you just use your special powers to escape? Teleportation and that kind of thing?
JANE: The Cube is built from a special metal which nullifies psychic energy.
CHARLEY: But your powers still work. You can still read my mind.
JANE: We still have some powers, but they're weakened in here.
CHARLEY: So the walls in this place act as a sort of psychic ball and chain.
LATCH: Or a muzzle.
CHARLEY: How many of you are there in here now?
JANE: Well, now that Marcus is dead, that only leaves Latch and me. And Tessa, of course.
CHARLEY: Tessa?
LATCH: The weak link in our chain. A loner. No, scratch that. A loser.
JANE: Some say she was the most powerful Psych they ever made.
LATCH: That's debatable.
JANE: Latch and Tessa never really hit it off.
LATCH: Tessa isn't a team player. We were supposed to be a team, a unit.
CHARLEY: What happened?
LATCH: Tessa preferred to work on her own, closed her mind against us.
JANE: She was never against us, Latch. She thought you could kill her.
LATCH: She knew I never meant that. It was just an excuse.
JANE: But she was a powerful Psych. Teleport was her speciality. We always thought if anyone could find a way out of the Cube, then Tessa could.
CHARLEY: At the moment I'll settle for just finding the Doctor and C'Rizz.
LATCH: They're both dead.
JANE: You don't know that for certain.
LATCH: Don't tell me you've fallen for it as well, Jane? The Brainworm got them both.
CHARLEY: No, I won't believe that until. Well, until I have proof.
LATCH: It wouldn't be pretty.
CHARLEY: Even so.
CHARLEY: What was that?
LATCH: We've waited too long. Come on! Let's move.
CHARLEY: The Brainworm?
JANE: You can generally hear it coming. Let's go.
CHARLEY: Well, where are we going?
LATCH: You want to find your friends, don't you? Come on, then. Just don't blame me if you don't like what you find.
DOCTOR: So what's next in your little bully's handbook of terror? Electric shock treatment? Matchsticks under the fingernails?
RAWDEN: We're a bit more advanced than that. We have a machine here, Doctor, which rewrites brainwaves. We used it to increase extra-sensory perception. That's how we created Latch and his kind. Psychic soldiers. It was probably a mistake, in hindsight, but the war. Well, to tell you the truth, it was a desperate time.
DOCTOR: And it called for desperate measures, I suppose.
RAWDEN: Exactly. I suppose it's true that making the Psychs was a terrible thing. It wasn't a decision that I took lightly. But I genuinely believe the Psychs won us the war.
DOCTOR: Bravo. Did they know that their reward would be a prison sentence?
RAWDEN: Perhaps they should have foreseen it, yes.
DOCTOR: (laughs) Being psychic.
RAWDEN: (laughs) Yes. You know, you and I, we could be friends, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I very much doubt it.
RAWDEN: Aw. We're both perceptive, intelligent men, strong-willed, determined. Yes, we're very alike.
DOCTOR: Now you are frightening me.
RAWDEN: Good.
LATCH: Tessa? Tessa, are you in there?
TESSA: You know I am, Latch. You'd better come in. Who's that with you? Charley who?
CHARLEY: Pollard. And please stop trying to read my mind.
TESSA: It's hard not to. Your thoughts light up like halogen in this place.
CHARLEY: Ow!
TESSA: It's a bit cramped, I know. I've fallen on hard times lately.
JANE: Haven't we all?
TESSA: Are you all right, Charley?
CHARLEY: Oh, a bang on the head, that's all. Oh. Well, I wouldn't try and read my mind right now, if I were you. It's likely to be a bit of a mess.
TESSA: Now don't be silly. Here, let me see.
CHARLEY: Ow!
TESSA: Oh, that's quite a lump. Never mind, it'll soon (pause) go away.
CHARLEY: Oh. Oh, that is better. Thank you. What did you do?
TESSA: Nothing, really. A parlour trick. I have healing hands. Cuts and contusions a speciality.
JANE: Tessa was our medic. She's being modest.
TESSA: But this is quite a deputation. Come to make me an offer I can't refuse, Latch?
LATCH: You've nothing to fear from me.
TESSA: Is that so? You hate me, but you need me. That can be a very ugly combination.
JANE: We've not come here to fight.
TESSA: No, you've come to parade your hostage.
CHARLEY: Hostage?
TESSA: That's what they're thinking, Charley. That they can use you to get out of here. And they may be right.
CHARLEY: Is this true?
JANE: We just want to get out of here.
LATCH: And we'll do whatever we have to.
TESSA: Latch, will you never give up?
LATCH: You know the answer to that.
CHARLEY: You don't need me as a hostage. To be honest, I don't think there's anyone here who'd care what happens to me. But I'm willing to help, for what it's worth. Surely there must be some way out? I mean, if there's a way in, then
TESSA: Makes sense. Yes.
LATCH: Tessa was our infiltration expert. In the old days, no one was better at teletransportation than Tessa.
CHARLEY: And now?
TESSA: I can't teleport myself out of here. It's psych proof.
CHARLEY: I know.
TESSA: But how did you and your chums get in? What is it about that big blue box of yours?
CHARLEY: The Tardis! You've seen it? Where is it?
TESSA: I can see it in your thoughts. Big and blue and full of hope and promise and safety. But what is it?
CHARLEY: Well, er, it's difficult to say.
TESSA: A time machine? That can't be right. Yet I can see you believe it. Oh, and they think I'm crazy. But I can see you don't really know all that much about it, how it works or anything. Not that that matters much now. Your Tardis isn't here any more, but the Doctor. Yes! He's the one. He's the one you want.
CHARLEY: Will you stop reading my mind, please. It's horrible.
TESSA: What? Wait, no. This Doctor person you keep thinking about.
LATCH: The Doctor's dead. The Brainworm got him.
CHARLEY: We don't know that for sure.
TESSA: Don't we? I can sense your thoughts, and those of Latch and Jane here. I cannot, however, detect the Doctor's thoughts anywhere. Nothing at all.
CHARLEY: What? What about C'Rizz?
TESSA: Nothing. I'm sorry, Charley. Your friends are gone, just like Marcus.
CHARLEY: No.
DOCTOR: This brainwave machine of yours, how does it work?
RAWDEN: I'm not technically minded. I believe it involves something called braincell augmentation, yes?
DOCTOR: That's interesting.
RAWDEN: Oh? Why?
DOCTOR: Oh, nothing. It's just a thought.
RAWDEN: What, exactly?
DOCTOR: Well, I imagine a machine like that, if it was sophisticated enough, could be used to repair neural damage.
RAWDEN: I think I see what you're getting at, Doctor. It might even be able to help you regain your memory. Quite ingenious. Are you serious?
DOCTOR: Well, no, actually. It's ridiculous. Forget I said it. Too risky, for one thing. It was just a mad thought. Ignore me.
RAWDEN: You're not an easy man to ignore, Doctor. You know, I think it's high time I introduced you to Mister Twyst.
DOCTOR: Mister Twyst?
